quest_title: Two coherent monochromatic light beams of intensities I and 4I are superposed. The maximum and minimum possible intensities in the resulting beam are
explanation_txt:
Intensity of a wave is proportional to square of its amplitude i.e. \(I\propto A^{2}\)

For two waves,

\(\cfrac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\cfrac{A_{1}^{2}}{A_{2}^{2}}=\cfrac{4}{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{A_{1}}{A_{2}}=\cfrac{2}{1}\)

When the waves superimpose constructively, amplitude of the resulting wave is the sum of amplitude of individual waves

i.e. \(A_{\text{max}}=2+1=3\)

When the waves superimpose destructively, amplitude of the resulting wave is the difference of amplitude of individual waves

i.e. \(A_{\text{min}}=2-1=1\)

Now, ratio of maximum and minimum intensities of the resulting wave \(=\cfrac{I_{\text{max}}}{I_{\text{min}}}=\cfrac{A_{\text{max}}^{2}}{A_{\text{min}}^{2}}=\cfrac{3^{2}}{1^{2}}=\cfrac{9}{1}\)

Shorcut formula:

\(\begin{aligned} I _ { \max } & = \left( \sqrt { I _ { 1 } } + \sqrt { I _ { 2 } } \right) ^ { 2 } = ( \sqrt { I } + \sqrt { 4 I } ) ^ { 2 } = 9 I \\ I _ { \min } & = \left( \sqrt { I _ { 1 } } - \sqrt { I _ { 2 } } \right) ^ { 2 } = ( \sqrt { I } - \sqrt { 4 I } ) ^ { 2 } = I \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: Two coherent monochromatic light beams of intensities I and 4I are superposed. The maximum and minimum possible intensities in the resulting beam are
explanation_plain_text:
Intensity of a wave is proportional to square of its amplitude i.e.

explanation_txt:
\(h=u \sin \theta t-\cfrac{1}{2} g t^{2} \)
\(\text { or, } 5=25 \sin \theta \times 2-\cfrac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 2^{2} \)
\(\text { or, } \sin \theta=\cfrac{1}{2}=\sin 30^{\circ} \)
\(\therefore \theta=30^{\circ} \)

quest_title: The equivalent resistance across B and C is
explanation_txt:
\(r^{\prime}=\cfrac{r}{2}+\cfrac{r}{2}\)

\(r^{\prime}=r\)

\( \therefore \quad R_{B C}= \cfrac{r \times \cfrac{r}{2}}{r+\cfrac{r}{2}}=\cfrac{r \times r}{2 \times \cfrac{3 r}{2}} \)

\( \therefore \quad R_{B C}=\cfrac{r}{3} \)
question_plain_title: The equivalent resistance across B and C is

quest_title: The length of potentiometer wire is 100cm and the emf of the standard cell is E volt. It is employed to measure the emf of a battery of internal resistance 0.5?. If the balance point is obtained at length l=30cm from the positive end, the emf of the battery is
explanation_txt:
Potential gradient \(\mathrm{K}=\cfrac{V_{A B}}{L_{A B}}\)
\(=\cfrac{E-i r}{100} \mathrm{v} / \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{E}=\mathrm{K} l=\cfrac{E-\mathrm{ir}}{100} \times 30\)
\(\quad=\cfrac{30(E-0.5 i)}{100}\)
question_plain_title: The length of potentiometer wire is 100cm and the emf of the standard cell is E volt. It is employed to measure the emf of a battery of internal resistance 0.5?. If the balance point is obtained at length l=30cm from the positive end, the emf of the battery is
explanation_plain_text: Potential gradient

quest_title: In given figure, what is the magnetic field induction at point O?
explanation_txt:
Magnetic field (B) at O will be due to the following portions:

(i) Vertical straight portion,
\( B_{\text {vert}}=0\)

(ii) Due to circular potion
\(B \text { circular }=\cfrac{1}{2} \cfrac{\mu_{0} i}{2 r}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i}{4 r}\)

(iii) Straight horizontal portion,
\(B_{\text {straight }}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i}{4 \pi r}\)

\(\therefore B_{\text {total}}=B_{\text {circular }}+B_{\text {straight }}+B_{\text {vertical}} \)
\(B_{\text {total}}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}i}{4 r}+\cfrac{\mu_{0 }i}{4 \pi r} \)

explanation_txt:

quest_title: 2.0 moles of \(\text{PCl\(_{5}\)}\) are placed in a 5.0 litre container and at equilibrium for the system \(\text{PCl\(_{5}\)(g)}\)   \(\leftrightharpoons\) \(\text{PCl\(_{3}\)}\) + \(\text{Cl\(_{2}\),}\) 0.40 mole of \(\text{Cl\(_{2}\)}\) is present. explanation_txt:
Given:

Initial concentration of \(PCl_5\) is \(2/5=0.4\)

\(\begin{matrix} &PCl_5 &\rightleftharpoons & PCl_3 & + & Cl_2 \\ C_0 : &0.4&&0&&0 \\ C : &x&&0.4-x&&0.4-x \end{matrix} \\ 0.4-x = 0.4/5=0.08 \\ \Rightarrow x = 0.32 \\ \Rightarrow K = \cfrac{0.08 \times 0.08}{0.32} = 0.02\)

Other chemicals are:

  • Copper Glance \( \to \quad Cu_2S \)

quest_title: Which is correct about ionisation potential ?
ans2_txt: It increases with increase in atomic radii
ans3_txt: It remains constant with increase in atomic radii
ans4_txt: It decreases with increase in atomic radii
explanation_txt:
Ionisation potential gradually decreases moving down the group because atomic size increases as we move down the group.

Hence larger the atomic size, smaller will be the ionisation potential.

quest_title: If the sum of the coefficients in the expansion of \((4 x - 5 y + 3 z ) ^ { n }\) is 128 then the greatest coefficient in the expansion of \((1+x)^n\) is
explanation_txt:
For sum of coefficients, \( x = y = z =1\)

So, \(128 = (4-5+3)^n = 2^n \Rightarrow n = 7 \)

The greatest coefficient occurs in middle term. The middle term is 3rd or 4th term.

So, coefficient is \( C(7,3) = 35 \)

quest_title: Iodethane when strongly heated with metallic sodium in etherial.
explanation_txt:
Iodoethane gives butane when strongly heated with metallic sodium in presence of dry ether.

\(CH_3CH_2I+2Na+ICH_2CH_3 \to \underset{Butane}{CH_3CH_2CH_2CH_3} + 2NaI\)

This reaction is known as Wurtz's reaction.
question_plain_title: Iodethane when strongly heated with metallic sodium in etherial.
explanation_plain_text:
Iodoethane gives butane when strongly heated with metallic sodium in presence of dry ether.

This reaction is known as Wurtz's reaction.

explanation_txt:
For the points of intersection, \(y_1 = y_2 \)

\( \Rightarrow 4x -x^2 = x^2-x \\ \Rightarrow 2x^2 - 5x = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x(2x-5) = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x =0 \, or \, 5/2 \)

The roots of \(4x -x^2 \) are \( x = 0, 4 \). So, there are no roots in the interval \( (0,5/2) \). The curve lies entirely above \(X\) axis. [verify for some \(x \in (0,5/2) \) ]

Similarly, the roots of \(x^2-x\) are \(x = 0,1 \). There is a root in the desired interval. So the curve lies below \(X\) axis for \( 0 < x < 1 \) and above it for \( 1 < x < 5/2 \).

Based on these observations, the following graph can be drawn: [red curve represents \(x^2-x\) and the green one represents \(4x-x^2\)]

The area above \(X\) axis is:

\[ \begin{align} A_1 & = \int_{0}^{1} (4x - x^2) dx + \int_{1}^{2.5} (5x-2x^2)dx \\ & = \left[ 2x^2 - \cfrac{x^3}{3} \right]_0^1 + \left[2.5x^2 - \cfrac{2}{3} x^3 \right]_1^{2.5} \\ & = \cfrac{5}{3} + \cfrac{27}{8} \\ & = \cfrac{121}{24} \end{align} \]

The area below \(X\) axis is:

\[ \begin{align} A_2 & = -\int_0^1 (x^2-x)dx \\ & = \left[ \cfrac{x^2}{2} - \cfrac{x^3}{3} \right]_0^1 = \cfrac{1}{6} \end{align} \]

So, the ratio is: \[ \cfrac{121}{24} \times 6 = 121 : 4 \]

quest_title: A bullet is fired into a target loses half of its velocity after penetrating 25 cm. The further penetrated by it before coming to rest is
explanation_txt:
First case,

\(\cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\cfrac{1}{2} m\left(\cfrac{v}{2}\right)^{2}=Fs\)
or, \(\quad \cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2} \times \cfrac{1}{4}=F \times 25\)
or, \(\quad \cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2} \times \cfrac{3}{4}=F \times 25 \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (1)

Second case,

\(\cfrac{1}{2} m\left(\cfrac{v}{2}\right)^{2}=F s^{\prime}\)
or, \(\quad \cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2} \times \cfrac{1}{4}=F s^{\prime} \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (2)

Dividing (2) by (1),

\(\cfrac{s^{\prime}}{25}=\cfrac{1 / 4}{3 / 4}\)
\(s^{\prime}=\cfrac{25}{3}=8.3 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: The sine of angle made by line with 0\({}^{0}\) c axis when graph is plotted between \({}^{0}\) c and \({}^{0}\) F is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\Delta F}{\Delta C}=\cfrac{9}{5}=\cfrac{A B}{B C}=\operatorname{Tan} \theta\)

\(\begin{aligned} \sin \theta &=\cfrac{1}{\cos e c \theta} \\ &=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+\cot ^{2} \theta}} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{=\cfrac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}}} \\ {=\cfrac{9 / 5}{\sqrt{1+\left(\cfrac{9}{5}\right)^{2}}}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{=\cfrac{9}{5} \times \cfrac{5}{\sqrt{106}}} \\ {=\cfrac{9}{\sqrt{106}}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The thermal capacity of a body is 80 cal, then its water equivalent is
explanation_txt:
We know that thermal capacity of a body expressed in calories is equal to water equivalent of the body expressed in grams.

Since specific heat of water is 1 cal/gm, water equivalent of 80 cal = \(\cfrac{80 \text{ cal}}{1 \text{ cal/gm}}=80 \text{ gm}\)

quest_title: Polarized glass is used in sun glasses because
ans1_txt: It reduces the light intensity to half an account of polarization
explanation_txt:
From Malus's law,

\(I = I _ { 0 } \cos ^ { 2 } \theta\)

\(\therefore\) Sun glasses are used to reduce intensity of sunlight which is unpolarized.

quest_title: A person feels 2.5\% difference of frequency of a motor-car horn. If the motor-car is moving to the person and the velocity of sound is 320 \(\textit{m}\)/\(\textit{sec}\), then the velocity of car will be
explanation_txt:
By Doppler's formula \(n'=n\cfrac{v}{(v-v_{S} )} \)

Since, source is moving towards the listener so \(n'>n\).

If \(\textit{n} = 100\) then \(\textit{n}' = 102.5\),

\(\Rightarrow 102.5=100\times \cfrac{320}{(320-v_{S} )} \Rightarrow v_{s} =8m/\sec \)

explanation_plain_text:
By Doppler's formula

ans4_plain_text: 6 / (approx.)

quest_title: The ratio of the energy of a photon with \(\lambda = 150 \mathrm { mm }\) to that with \(\lambda = 300 \mathrm { mm }\) is
explanation_txt: \(E = \cfrac { h c } { \lambda } \Rightarrow \cfrac { E _ { 1 } } { E _ { 2 } } = \cfrac{\lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{1}}=\cfrac { 300 } { 150 } = \cfrac { 2 } { 1 }\)
